Those holes can be utilized to produce plenty of H with water.Meanwhile, the photo-generated electrons are involved in a series of photocatalytic reactions with a multi-electron process. 4,17,5253354 Briey, the adsorbed CO 2 on the surface is rstly reduced into HCOOH species with 2e A and 2H .Then these intermediate products are subsequently reduced into HCHO, CH 3 OH and CH 4 species step by step. 5556657 Besides, the 2e A from g-C 3 N 4 and 2H from the surrounding environment are required for each step of the reaction.Finally, the CO 2 molecules can be converted into CH 4 and CH 3 OH chemical fuels under the irradiation of light. The charge transfer dynamics taking place on the bulk-CN and NS-CN were analysed by transient photocurrent responses, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), and timeresolved photoluminescence (TRPL) spectroscopy.As shown in Fig. 13a, the photocurrent intensity of NS-CN is notably higher than that of the bulk-CN with several on-off cycles of light irradiation, indicating more efficient electron-hole pair transfer and separation on the NS-CN photocatalyst.Note that the current intensity of NS-CN shows a gradual increase as the light is turned on, and gradual decrease as the light is turned off.Such a phenomenon is caused by the relaxation effect during excitation and de-excitation processes. 39,58For NS-CN, the number of surface delocalized p bonds is higher than that for the bulk-CN due to the larger number of exposed aromatic heterocycles aer exfoliation.A large portion of photogenerated electrons in the conduction band of NS-CN can be gradually accumulated because of these delocalized p bonds.Therefore, the photocurrent gradually increased due to the photogenerated electrons stored in these delocalized p bonds.On the other hand, when the light is turned off, the stored electrons are gradually released from the surface delocalized p bonds and then transferred to the working electrode, leading to a gradual decrease of the photocurrent to zero.Hence, the enrichment of photogenerated electrons in the delocalized p bonds can reduce the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes, and consequently facilitate the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 molecules and formation of CH 4 and CH 3 OH, which are eightelectron and six-electron processes of CO 2 photoreduction, respectively. EIS Nyquist plots obtained for the bulk-CN and NS-CN are shown in Fig. 13b.In the analog equivalent circuit (inset of Fig. 13b), R ctr represents the charge-transfer resistance of the working electrode, R sr represents the solution resistance (Na 2 SO 4 ), and CPE represents the constant phase element between the electrolyte solution and electrode.The size of the semicircular arc in the Nyquist plots here reects R ctr , 59 which is estimated as 2.2 and 6.4 kU for NS-CN and bulk-CN, respectively.Namely, a smaller semicircle radius implies lower charge-transfer resistance and thus a faster charge-transfer rate in NS-CN due to its ultrathin structure. The TRPL spectra were further recorded to investigate the lifetime of photogenerated charge carriers as shown in Fig. 13c.The curves of both bulk-CN and NS-CN can be well tted through a bi-exponential function. 6061162 The short lifetime, long lifetime, and average lifetime are 2.8, 9.5, and 6.7 ns for NS-CN, and 1.5, 6.3, and 3.4 ns for the bulk-CN, respectively.The results indicate that the lifetimes of photogenerated charge carriers in NS-CN have been remarkably prolonged as compared to those obtained for the bulk-CN, which is due to the strong electron capture ability of the surface states in NS-CN.This result combined with the transient photocurrent response and EIS analysis indicates that a signicantly enhanced transfer and separation efficiency can be achieved over the NS-CN photocatalyst, which is one of the crucial factors to facilitate the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.
